content: The Act titled "Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999" is established for the purpose of improving wireless communications for public safety. The Congress finds that establishing an end-to-end communications infrastructure among various emergency response entities will reduce response times, prevent fatalities, reduce injuries, save lives, and lower healthcare costs. This coordination is crucial for the rapid deployment of emergency telecommunications services. The establishment of funding for emergency technology development, coordination of emergency communications with traffic systems, and the use of emerging technologies to improve emergency response times are crucial for public safety. The purpose of this Act is to encourage the deployment of a reliable wireless telecommunications system to improve emergency care systems and promote public safety. The Act aims to establish a seamless, ubiquitous, and reliable end-to-end infrastructure for communications, including wireless communications, to meet the Nation's public safety and other communication needs. The Act establishes a universal emergency telephone number. The Communications Act of 1934 amends Section 251(e) to designate 9-1-1 as the universal emergency telephone number in the United States for reporting emergencies and requesting assistance, applicable to both wireline and wireless services. Transition periods will be provided for areas where 9-1-1 is not currently in use. The Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999 mandates the deployment of comprehensive emergency communications infrastructure and programs, including reliable wireless networks and enhanced 9-1-1 service. The Federal Communications Commission will work with states, local officials, telecommunications industry, motor vehicle manufacturers, and emergency service providers to support this deployment. The Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999 mandates the deployment of emergency communications infrastructure. Safety officials, consumer groups, and healthcare personnel are encouraged to develop statewide deployment plans. Wireless carriers and their personnel are granted immunity in states to the same extent as liability protection. The Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999 mandates emergency communications infrastructure deployment. Local exchange companies and wireless 9-1-1 service users are granted immunity or protection from liability in connection with releasing subscriber information for emergency services. The Wireless Communications and Public Safety Act of 1999 mandates emergency communications infrastructure deployment. In matters related to wireless 9-1-1 communications, a PSAP and its employees, vendors, agents, and authorizing government entity shall have immunity or protection from liability under applicable law. This section is enacted as an exercise of Congress's enforcement power under the Fourteenth Amendment and the power to regulate commerce. SEC. 5. AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE CUSTOMER INFORMATION. Section 222 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to provide call location information for emergency services and to notify the user's family in case of an emergency. The amendment to Section 222 of the Communications Act allows for the use of wireless location information for emergency services without customer authorization. This includes notifying the user's immediate family in emergency situations involving the risk of death or serious harm. The amendment to Section 222 of the Communications Act permits the sharing of automatic crash notification information for emergency services. Telecommunications carriers must provide subscriber information for emergency services purposes promptly and fairly. The amendment to Section 222 of the Communications Act allows for the sharing of automatic crash notification information for emergency services, including defining terms like public safety answering point, emergency services, emergency notification services, and emergency support services. The amendment to Section 222 of the Communications Act defines terms related to emergency services, such as public safety answering point, emergency notification services, and emergency support services. The Act defines key terms related to emergency services, including the Secretary of Transportation, States, public safety answering point (PSAP), wireless carrier, and enhanced wireless 9-1-1 service designated by the Federal Communications Commission. The Act defines terms related to emergency services, including wireless 9-1-1 service provided by a wireless carrier and emergency dispatch providers.
